Award.AwardTitle: Racial Discrimination, Coping, and Underlying Processes in African American Young Adults

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates how racial discrimination impacts African Americans' physiological functioning and psychological adjustment.

Intellectual Merit:

This research consists of two studies. The primary research aim of the first study is to combine experimental and ambulatory blood pressure monitoring approaches to examine how African Americans emotionally and physiologically respond to actual racial discrimination that occurs in the lab, over a 24-hour period. Additionally, the study explicates the processes that account for these relationships. The primary research aim of the second study is to examine whether eating as a coping strategy mitigates the impact of racial discrimination on emotional and physiological outcomes. This study also examines whether physiological coping processes mitigate the relationship between racial discrimination and emotional outcomes.

Broader Impacts:

This research has the potential to: (1) greatly enhance our understanding of how racial discrimination is psychologically experienced and capture the variability in African Americans' experiences; (2) identify the processes that explicate the link between racial discrimination and psychological adjustment and physiological functioning; (3) elucidate how racial discrimination is experienced over time; and (4) provide a conceptual framework and methodological approach that can be employed as tools for future studies. The studies provide an excellent opportunity to investigate causal attribution, cognitive appraisal, and coping processes as potential pathways for understanding the deleterious consequences of racial discrimination. In studying racial discrimination, the studies contribute to the current research literature by employing ecologically valid research designs in which African Americans actually experience racial discrimination. The findings from the research will help to determine whether racial discrimination is a distinct stressor with emotional and physiological consequences that exceed those of nonracial stressors and whether there is more to the experience of racial discrimination than what is currently captured in generic models of stress and coping. Additionally, the studies collectively elucidate the processes that underlie racial discrimination and the ways in which racial discrimination unfolds both within and beyond the laboratory context.

Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHAPEL HILL

Performance_Institution.Name: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cardiovascular disease (e.g., coronary artery disease) remains the leading cause of death in the U.S. The 2013 cardiovascular disease death rate per 100,000 Americans was 270.6 for White males, 356.7 for African American males, 183.8 for White females, and 246.6 for African American females (American Heart Association, 2015), indicating that African American men and and women experience the greatest cardiovascular disease mortality. Racial discrimination (e.g., being given poor service, being followed by a police officer) is still a common and stressful experience for African Americans. Notably, racial discrimination has been increasingly linked to risk for cardiovascular disease. Research shows that racial discrimination takes a serious biological toll on the bodies of African Americans, with consequences that include elevated blood pressure, increased heart rate, and decreased heart rate variability—an indicator of the cardiovascular system’s ability to appropriately respond to environmental challenges. Moreover, unhealthy coping strategies (e.g., emotional eating) employed to manage racial discrimination experiences may pose additional health risks. Over time, harmful biological responses and maladaptive coping strategies triggered by racial discrimination responses may contribute to disease risk.

The aims of this National Science Foundation grant were to examine the aforementioned biological and coping-related mechanisms accounting for the relationship among racial discrimination, harmful biological changes, and poorer health status. In Study one, 108 African American young adults arrived to the research lab and completed a battery of questionnaires, including questions assessing racial discrimination experiences and general health status. A key finding was that a greater accumulation of past year racial discrimination experiences was linked to poorer self-reported health. Moreover, the tendency to engage in emotional eating when experiencing anxiety- and anger-provoking events exacerbated or strengthened the relation between more accumulative racial discrimination and poorer health. We are currently reporting these findings in an article to be published in a peer-reviewed journal.

Study two utilized an innovative experimental lab approach to examine African Americans’ real-time physiological responses to racial discrimination. Approximately 70 African American young adult women arrived to the lab and were outfitted with physiological equipment assessing blood pressure, heart rate, heart rate variability, and various other physiological outcomes. The African American young adult women were then falsely accused of taking another individual’s (i.e., an actor’s) iPhone. We predicted that this racially discriminatory event would be associated with exaggerated physiological responses that have been implicated in premature death and disease. After being exposed to the racially discriminatory event, the African American young adult women were presented with sweet, fatty snack food. We hypothesized that the African American young adult women who responded the most negatively to the event would also consume the most snack food, suggesting that emotional eating may pose additional health risks in the face of racial discrimination. These study data are currently being prepped and analyzed, and will be submitted for publication in the upcoming months. 

The results of these two studies will potentially shed light on the biological mechanisms that account for the relationship between racial discrimination and poorer physical health, particularly cardiovascular health. These results will also potentially inform intervention efforts, highlighting the importance of supplanting African Americans’ harmful coping strategies (e.g., emotional eating) with more adaptive coping strategies. 

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2016
Modified by: Lori Hoggard
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Cardiovascular disease (e.g., coronary artery disease) remains the leading cause of death in the U.S. The 2013 cardiovascular disease death rate per 100,000 Americans was 270.6 for White males, 356.7 for African American males, 183.8 for White females, and 246.6 for African American females (American Heart Association, 2015), indicating that African American men and and women experience the greatest cardiovascular disease mortality. Racial discrimination (e.g., being given poor service, being followed by a police officer) is still a common and stressful experience for African Americans. Notably, racial discrimination has been increasingly linked to risk for cardiovascular disease. Research shows that racial discrimination takes a serious biological toll on the bodies of African Americans, with consequences that include elevated blood pressure, increased heart rate, and decreased heart rate variability—an indicator of the cardiovascular system?s ability to appropriately respond to environmental challenges. Moreover, unhealthy coping strategies (e.g., emotional eating) employed to manage racial discrimination experiences may pose additional health risks. Over time, harmful biological responses and maladaptive coping strategies triggered by racial discrimination responses may contribute to disease risk. The aims of this National Science Foundation grant were to examine the aforementioned biological and coping-related mechanisms accounting for the relationship among racial discrimination, harmful biological changes, and poorer health status. We are currently reporting these findings in an article to be published in a peer-reviewed journal. Study two utilized an innovative experimental lab approach to examine African Americans? real-time physiological responses to racial discrimination. Approximately 70 African American young adult women arrived to the lab and were outfitted with physiological equipment assessing blood pressure, heart rate, heart rate variability, and various other physiological outcomes. The African American young adult women were then falsely accused of taking another individual?s (i.e., an actor?s) iPhone. After being exposed to the racially discriminatory event, the African American young adult women were presented with sweet, fatty snack food. We hypothesized that the African American young adult women who responded the most negatively to the event would also consume the most snack food, suggesting that emotional eating may pose additional health risks in the face of racial discrimination. These study data are currently being prepped and analyzed, and will be submitted for publication in the upcoming months. The results of these two studies will potentially shed light on the biological mechanisms that account for the relationship between racial discrimination and poorer physical health, particularly cardiovascular health. These results will also potentially inform intervention efforts, highlighting the importance of supplanting African Americans? harmful coping strategies (e.g., emotional eating) with more adaptive coping strategies.
